title: 1478-C
statement: C. Nezzar and Symmetric Arraytime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputLong time ago there was a symmetric array $$$a_1,a_2,\\ldots,a_{2n}$$$ consisting of $$$2n$$$distinct integers. Array $$$a_1,a_2,\\ldots,a_{2n}$$$ is called symmetric if for each integer $$$1 \\le i \\le 2n$$$, there exists an integer $$$1 \\le j \\le 2n$$$ such that $$$a_i = -a_j$$$.For each integer $$$1 \\le i \\le 2n$$$, Nezzar wrote down an integer $$$d_i$$$ equal to the sum of absolute differences from $$$a_i$$$ to all integers in $$$a$$$, i. e. $$$d_i = \\sum_{j = 1}^{2n} {|a_i - a_j|}$$$.Now a million years has passed and Nezzar can barely remember the array $$$d$$$ and totally forget $$$a$$$. Nezzar wonders if there exists any symmetric array $$$a$$$ consisting of $$$2n$$$ distinct integers that generates the array $$$d$$$.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^5$$$) — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 10^5$$$).The second line of each test case contains $$$2n$$$ integers $$$d_1, d_2, \\ldots, d_{2n}$$$ ($$$0 \\le d_i \\le 10^{12}$$$).It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, print "YES" in a single line if there exists a possible array $$$a$$$. Otherwise, print "NO".You can print letters in any case (upper or lower).ExampleInput6 2 8 12 8 12 2 7 7 9 11 2 7 11 7 11 1 1 1 4 40 56 48 40 80 56 80 48 6 240 154 210 162 174 154 186 240 174 186 162 210OutputYES NO NO NO NO YESNoteIn the first test case, $$$a=[1,-3,-1,3]$$$ is one possible symmetric array that generates the array $$$d=[8,12,8,12]$$$.In the second test case, it can be shown that there is no symmetric array consisting of distinct integers that can generate array $$$d$$$.

processed.result:
You are given an array $d$ of $2n$ integers.  An array $a$ of $2n$ distinct integers is called symmetric if for each integer $1 \le i \le 2n$, there exists an integer $1 \le j \le 2n$ such that $a_i = -a_j$.

For each integer $1 \le i \le 2n$,  $d_i$ is the sum of the absolute differences from $a_i$ to all integers in $a$.

Determine if there exists a symmetric array $a$ that generates the array $d$.

Input:

* The first line contains an integer $t$ ($1 \le t \le 10^5$) - the number of test cases.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains an integer $n$ ($1 \le n \le 10^5$).
    * The second line contains $2n$ integers $d_1, d_2, ..., d_{2n}$ ($0 \le d_i \le 10^{12}$).

Output:

For each test case, print "YES" if there exists a possible array $a$. Otherwise, print "NO".
Given a list of numbers, determine if there exists a list of distinct numbers with the same length that, when paired with their opposites, would produce the given list of numbers.
